answers.answer: The TSH suggests significant hypothyroidism and needs to be treated -- but will take 5-6 weeks at least to normalize -- average replacement dose would be 100mcg in this setting.  Prolactin history may not be related, but hypothyrodism can cause increase in prolactin, so keep this in mind if prolactin is currently high.   Dizziness can occur in hypothyroidism.

Hi,You will need to take the thyroxine for more than two weeks.  Likely you will need replacement thyroid hormone for the rest of your life.What dose did your obe put you on?See Dr. Lupo's comment about average dose above.However, your actual requirement would be adjusted over a few months based on your blood test results.  Target TSH will probably be between 1.0 - 2.0.Best wishes.

Thank you for your reply. But, now i am more confused. My lab was TSH 38.31 two weeks ago, and today 4.30. Been on Thyroxine 100MCG daily for 2 weeks since the last blood work, but do not feel any better....infact i feel worse (Dizziness biggest issue now) My hair is STILL falling out and my fatigue....STILL HERE. Furthermore, i was thinking that my levels would take up to 5-6 weeks to adjust...Could this be a sign that something else is going on? If so...what should i consider ? Any info would be as always...VERY Helpful ;)

Hi,Your levels are looking better, however it may still take some time for you to feel better (and the retesting at 5 - 6 weeks will give you a better picture of what's going on once your levels have stabilised).Be patient with this for a few more weeks... it really does take a while to feel better as the thyroid meds are adjusted. (In my experience it took a few months to feel better from being hypo, even when the meds were correct)....You'll need to work with your endo (you'll see in Nov - December) and your doctor to screen for anything else going on, but primarily need to address the thyroid for now.  If still feeling bad in another month or so and your levels are ok, see if you can get bumped up to see the endocrinologist sooner.Best wishes
Thank you sooooo much for your response. I really appreciate it ;) Hope I get to feeling better too....This is NOT fun
I am glad to see Dr. Lupo list dizziness as a symptom of hypothroidism.

hi,i have silent thryoiditis (i am currently trying to get my tsh under control as well.  it was 55.86 now 9.29...i'm getting there slowly).  but no one in my family has a history of thyroid problems except me.  i think i've had this off and on several times throughout my life, but i'll never know since i didn't have labs run before.anyways, i see that you had a c-section...and i'm curious, did you have preeclampsia?  or pregnancy-induced hypertension?  i'm wondering because i had complications with both of my pregnancies...the first i had to have emergency c-section because of preeclampsia, hellp syndrome.   i also had high bp at the end of my second pregnancy and was put on bedrest.  no one in my family has history of pregnancy problems, so the issues with my pregnancies are unexplained.  i'm thinking it may be related to underlying thyroid issue.

Hi there,Well, actually, I had no problems that i know of while pregnant. However, it did take a while to conceive. So i am wondering if maybe i had issues from before as well that i was not aware of. I am guessing that maybe you did too, which is why you had some complications....I would think that since Thy. problems are soooooooooooooooo common with a lot of women that Dr.'s would run tests during pregnancy, i have no idea why they do not. Wouldn't it make sense that they do?

hello again.i would imagine that at the beginning of the pregnancy that baseline values are done on the thyroid.  but i really have no idea.  nothing was mentioned to me about things being out of whack, so i guess my values were fine.i'm trying to connect illnesses when there may not be a connection.  docs don't seem to know why some women get preeclampsia /hellp syndrome, so i was thinking the underlying thyroid issue could have contributed.i didn't have any issues conceiving...actually, it happened a little too easily..;)  thank goodness.  we're blessed in that regard because i can't imagaine what it would be like trying to conceive and not being able to.  that's rough.  i'm sorry to hear that it was difficult for you.  congrats on your new baby!!  babies are wonderful!  enjoy your little angel!

question: Hi,9mths ago i had a baby through a C-Section. Recently i have been having more than normal hair loss and off and on weird joint pain, so i decided to have my thyroid checked. The results were TSH of 38.31 and T4 of 5.4, so my OB gave my Thyroxine to take for 2 weeks and then repeat the tests. He said he is not very fmaliar with Thyroid issus. Further more, I was also treated 10 years ago for  hyperprolactinemia with bromocriptine and since then my prolactin levels have always been normal, including my recent test which showed 6.8. My mother has hyperthyroidism and so it does run in the family. I am concerned that my TSH was that high, is that normal? Would it be related to  hyperprolactinemia? I am not able to get an appointment with a specialist till Nov-Dec and so any information regarding the issue would be very VERY helpful. I have been feeling a little dizzy recently, not sure if that is a symptom, and there are rare times in the afternoon where i may feel very tired....but I am confused about the blood work. Please shed some light. I do not get to see a specialist till a couple of weeks from now and so i have no where to turn to for answers. thank you in advance for any info ;)
title: TSH 38.31, should I worry?
